explanation: 1) OS_filesys_internal_record_t — needed to see the declaration of the struct and the exact type of the member system_mountpt (e.g. char * vs const char *). That determines whether the pointer stored in the record could/should be const-qualified (MISRA: pointers should be to const where possible). 2) OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — the macro/inline used to obtain 'local' determines its return type (pointer-to-T vs pointer-to-const-T) and whether the code is forced to use a non-const pointer; this affects whether 'local' could be declared as const OS_filesys_internal_record_t *. 3) OS_object_token_t — the token type is used with OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(*token); its definition clarifies whether dereferencing token mutates state or requires non-const usage (and confirms that the incoming token parameter being const is appropriate). 4) statvfs (prototype from <sys/statvfs.h>) — the function parameter types (path as const char *) show that the path argument does not require a modifiable char*, so the field passed (system_mountpt) can be const-qualified if it is not modified elsewhere. 5) OS_statvfs_t — definition of the result struct and its members shows that 'result' is an output parameter that is written to; this confirms that making the result pointer const would be inappropriate. Together these symbols allow deciding if any pointer in the function (local, system_mountpt, token, or result) should be const-qualified per the MISRA rule.
